By Dean Swift.
An Inundation sais the Fable
O'er·flow'd a Farmer's Barn and Stable
Whole Ricks of Hay and Stacks of Corn
Were down the suddain current born.
While things of het'rogeneous kind
Together float with Tide and wind.
The generous Wheat forgot itshis pride
And saild with litter by erasedside-by-side,
Uniting all to shew their Amity
As in a general Calamity.
A Ball of newdrop'd Horses dung
Mingling with apples in the throng
Said to the pippin plump & trim
See Brother's how we apples swim.
Thus Lamb renown'd for cutting corns
An Offer'd Fee from Radcliff scorns
Not for the world──·──We Doctor's Brother
Must take no Fees from one an' other.
Thus to a Dean some Curate Sloven
Subscribes Dear Sir your Brother loveing.
Thus all the Footmen Shoeboys, porters
About St James·'s cry We Courtiers
Thus Horace in the House will prate
Sr- we the Ministers of State.
Thus at the Bar the Booby Bettsworth
Tho' half a crown out pays his Sweatsworth.
Who knows in law nor Text nor Margin
Calls Singleton his Bror
Sergeant
And thus Fanatick Saints, tho' neither in
Doctrine or Discipline Our Bretheren──
Are Brother Protestant and Christians added later
As much as Hebrews and Phylistians,
But in no other Sence than nature
Has made a Rat our fellow creature,
Lice from your body suck their food
But is a Louse your flesh and blood,
Tho' born of human filth and Sweat it
may not be said man did beget it.
For Maggot in the nose and Chin
As well may claim you for their kin.
Yet Criticks may object why not
Since Lice are Bretheren to a Scot
Which made our Swarm of Scots determine
Imployment for their Brother Vermin,
But be they Irish English Scotish
What Protestant can be so Sottish
While Or'e the Church these Clowds are gathering
To call a Swarm of Lice their Bretheren
As Moses by divine Advice
In Egypt turn'd the Dust to Lice
And as our Scots by all descriptions
Have hearts more harden'd than Egyptians
As from the trodden dust they spring
And turn'd to Lice infest the King.
For pitty' sake it would be just
A Rod should turn them back to dust.
Let Folkes in high and holy stations
Be prowdproud of owning such Relations.
Let Courtiers hug them to their bosom
As if they were afraid to loose 'em.
